data.title: VS Code requires git ssh keys to be named as "id_rsa"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 
  
  Version 1.6.1
  Commit 9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e
  Date 2016-10-13T15:43:46.054Z
  Shell 1.3.7
  Renderer 52.0.2743.82
  Node 6.5.0
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Create a ssh-key for github with filename something other than id_rsa (ex: github_key_id_rsa)
2. Try to push to the remote github repository

VS Code's git push fails with error messages:

> Please make sure you have the correct access rights
> and the repository exists.
> git fetch
> Permission denied (publickey).
> fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Push to repo on the command line with `git push` works. If I rename the key to id_rsa then the push operations work fine

data.title: Keyboard reference should get some UI love
data.body:
I find our keybinding PDF a bit boring, especially hard to distinguish a keybinding from a command. In the end we want people to print this out and put it over their desk or even print T-Shirts with it.

Inspirations:
- Atom cheat sheet http://d2wy8f7a9ursnm.cloudfront.net/atom-editor-cheat-sheet.pdf
- Sublime cheat sheet https://www.cheatography.com/martinprins/cheat-sheets/sublime-text-3-osx/

data.title: Editor: snap to minimize is not cleared in all cases
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. open 3 editors
2. change to horizontal editor layout
3. make one maximized so that the others are minimized (e.g. by sash dragging)
4. close all editors
5. open 3 editors
6. move the panel up from below until the editors are totally minimized
7. move the panel down again

=> the editors should restore accordingly
=> bug, only the editor that was maximized before gets size back

The issue is that we fail to clear the minimized state when closing or opening editors and their sizes change.

data.title: Support HTML comments in Markdown
data.body:
Hi :raising_hand_man: 

This PR do:
- Remove Java comment syntax, because is not valid in Markdown
- Add HTML block comments supported by Markdown

data.title: Allow to set image as background of explorer panel
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Any
- OS Version: Any

Hi,
So I recently started testing vscode coming from atom, and I'm proooobably here to stay :-P
The one thing I'd like to do is set a background image in the explorer panel.

Nothing fancy, I don't need an easy way to do it.
In fact, it's probably already possible with some fancy CSS file I can drop somewhere?

But Atom lets you do it through themes, so I figured I'd create this ticket for the possibility.

I clicked the "Related projects" link in the guidelines for contributing, and it guided me to the "vs themes" project, but that only seems related to icon themes and syntax themes from what I could tell. So please do excuse me if this is the wrong place for the ticket.

Thank you.

data.title: Add Option to Disable "Alt" Showing Menu Bar When Toggled to be Hidden
data.body:
The Menu Bar can be hidden through a setting/toggle, when it is toggled to be hidden the "alt" key is used to make it temporarily visible again. Certain shortcuts require the "alt" button and most of the time I don't mean to reveal the Menu Bar but I simply misclick a shortcut which causes the menu bar to rapidly flicker open and then closed. So having an option to disable "alt" from toggling the menu would be appreciated.

I've looked through the keyboard shortcut settings and I didn't find anything associated with it there.

data.title: UI scrolls when tabbing around in narrow window
data.body:
- Enable 'tab moves focus'. You can't see it in this gif because of #12941, but it's enabled.
- Make the window narrow enough so that the editor buttons in the top right are off the page
- When you tab to them, the whole page scrolls to them so the sidebar is hidden.

Reproes in both 1.7-insiders and 1.6.

data.title: [javascript] Shebang should be highlighted as a line comment.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: OS X Sierra

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Switch language to JavaScript (or TypeScript)
2. Type shebang into the first line
3. Expect it _not_ to be parsed with JavaScript grammar.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8125011/19746156/183dc37e-9ba3-11e6-893c-28d7ca2fe1b4.png)

data.title: Issue with vscode.workspace.getConfiguration
data.body:
- Install the python extension
- Create a folder with one python file
- Open in vscode and see that you have python intellisense. 
- Close/reopen vscode on the same folder
- Now the extension fails to load with this error - 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19744550/d2e1b120-9b82-11e6-8b48-6e76fe930645.png)

This works in stable. Debugging, it looks like an issue with these lines -

``` typescript
let pythonSettings = vscode.workspace.getConfiguration('python');
this.pythonPath = systemVariables.resolveAny(pythonSettings.get<string>('pythonPath'));
```

The first time the folder is opened, (and every time in stable), `pythonSettings.get('pythonPath')` returns 'python', which is the default value of that setting. If I add a settings.json file in the workspace with 'python' or some other interpreter, it works. Otherwise, it seems like vscode is doing the wrong thing.

data.title: New Toggle Maximize Panel command should have a keybinding
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.7.0 insiders
- OS Version:Windows 10

Toggle commands should have a keybinding and users will want to quickly maximize then shrink the panel.
Perhaps a binding with Ctrl+Shift to match other panel commands. How about Ctrl+Shift+A?

data.title: VSCode Debug: No Configuration loaded when .vscode/launch.json is on a network share.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 10.0.14393

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In VSCode, open a folder using a UNC share path (\server\share\somefolder)
2. Go to Debug and try to debug a Powershell script
3. Use the Gear symbol to create the launch.json for Powershell
4. The Debug drop down will always say "No Configuration"

Trying this on a local path seems to work fine.

data.title: Feature Request:  Find in files>Replace All option to save and close

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.7.0-insider
- OS Version: 10.12.1

Currently when you execute "find in files" and want to replace multiple items in many files, the files all open into the editor.  You then need to either save each or "save all", and then close them all.

It would be nice to have an option to do the bulk replace without the files needing to open at all in the workspace, as is possible with Atom and Sublime.
